question: [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Signature forgery] At line 156, verify_arbitrary_msg() is called from the underlying crypto library - if this has a vulnerability allowing signature forgery for multi-sig schemes, can attackers sign arbitrary transactions without controlling threshold private keys? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Gas calculation overflow] At lines 149-154, complex gas calculation involving multiplication of num_sub_sigs with multiple gas parameters and msg.len() - can integer overflow in this calculation allow attackers to pay near-zero gas for expensive signature verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Deserialization bypass] At lines 134-138, MultiEd25519PublicKey::try_from() can fail and return false - does this allow attackers to submit malformed public keys that bypass signature verification entirely by making the function return false early? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Threshold manipulation] When deserializing MultiEd25519PublicKey at line 134, does the underlying try_from properly validate that threshold is between 1 and n, or can attackers provide threshold=0 or threshold>n to break multi-sig security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Signature deserialization bypass] At lines 142-146, MultiEd25519Signature::try_from() failure returns false - does this mean malformed signatures are treated as invalid rather than causing transaction failure, potentially allowing replay attacks with modified signatures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Bitmap manipulation] When deserializing signatures, does the bitmap validation ensure that bitmap indices match the provided signatures, or can attackers manipulate the bitmap to reference wrong public keys for signature verification? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Gas-before-deserialization pattern] Lines 133 and 141 charge gas before deserialization attempts - if deserialization is maliciously expensive, can attackers cause validator slowdown while paying only deserialization gas but not verification gas? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Type casting safety] At lines 130-131, casting pubkey.len() and signature.len() to u64 for NumArgs - can truncation on systems where usize > u64 cause incorrect gas calculation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Message size attack] At line 152, ED25519_PER_MSG_BYTE_HASHING is multiplied by msg.len() - can attackers provide extremely large messages to cause integer overflow in gas calculation or memory exhaustion during verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Verification result handling] At line 156, verify_arbitrary_msg returns Result - does is_ok() properly distinguish between verification failure and internal errors? Could internal errors be misinterpreted as valid signatures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [per::<Arg>() conversion] At line 152, converting gas from per-byte to per-argument basis - can this conversion have rounding errors that allow attackers to pay less gas than actual verification cost? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [Debug assertion bypass] At lines 121-122, debug_assert! checks ty_args and arguments length - in release builds these are not checked, can this cause undefined behavior if called with wrong arguments? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_signature_verify_strict()] [SafeNativeResult error propagation] If any gas charge operation returns Err, does the error properly propagate or could it be silently ignored, allowing free verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_generate_keys()] [Testing feature leak] This function is only enabled with 'testing' feature flag - if this feature accidentally gets enabled in production builds, can anyone generate unlimited multi-sig keypairs on-chain without cryptographic randomness source validation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_generate_keys()] [OsRng security] At line 169, OsRng is used for key generation - if OsRng is predictable or compromised on validator nodes, can attackers predict generated keys and steal funds? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_generate_keys()] [unwrap() panic] At line 179, MultiEd25519PrivateKey::new().unwrap() will panic if threshold validation fails - can this crash validator nodes during testing if invalid n/threshold values are provided? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_generate_keys()] [Gas metering absence] This function has no gas charges - in testing mode, can it be abused to generate unlimited keys causing validator resource exhaustion? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_generate_keys()] [Integer overflow in loop] At line 168, iterating 0..n where n is u8 - if n=255, can loop iteration cause issues or unexpected behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_generate_keys()] [Threshold validation bypass] Does line 179's new() properly validate that threshold <= n and threshold > 0, or can invalid configurations be created in testing mode? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_sign()] [Testing feature leak] Like generate_keys, if 'testing' feature is enabled in production, can attackers use this to sign arbitrary messages with private keys they shouldn't have access to? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_sign()] [unwrap() panic] At line 195, MultiEd25519PrivateKey::try_from().unwrap() will panic on invalid private key bytes - can this crash validator nodes during testing? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_sign()] [No gas metering] This testing function charges no gas - could it be abused to perform expensive signing operations repeatedly? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: native_sign()] [Signature determinism] At line 196, sign_arbitrary_message() - is the signature deterministic or randomized? If randomized, could this cause non-deterministic behavior in testing that masks bugs? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: make_all()] [Function naming collision] If function names like 'public_key_validate_internal' at line 211 collide with other native functions, can this cause undefined behavior or function shadowing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/natives/cryptography/multi_ed25519.rs] [Function: make_all()] [Conditional compilation mismatch] Testing natives are conditionally compiled at lines 224-230 - if Move code calls these functions but they're not compiled in, does this cause runtime errors or silent failures? (Medium)
